description.plain: Chaka Khan (born Yvette Marie Stevens, March 23, 1953) is an American recording artist whose career has spanned five decades, beginning in the 1970s as the lead vocalist and focal point of the funk band Rufus. Known as the Queen of Funk, Khan was the first R&B artist to have a crossover hit featuring a rapper, with “I Feel for You” in 1984. Khan has won ten Grammys and has sold an estimated 70 million records worldwide. Ms. Stevens has two children, Milini Khan, and Damien Holland.

songs.full_title: Reading Rainbow Theme Song by Chaka Khan
songs.title: Reading Rainbow Theme Song

description.plain:
After using the same iconic theme song originally sung by disco soul singer Tina Fabrique for 16 years, children’s television show Reading Rainbow replaced the beloved intro in 2001 with a new one recorded by 10-time Grammy Award winner Chaka Khan.

Reading Rainbow was on television from June 6, 1983 to November 10, 2006 and is the fourth-longest running children’s show on PBS. During its span of 21 seasons and 155 episodes, Reading Rainbow won over 200 broadcast awards, including a Peabody Award as well as 26 Emmy Awards.

songs.full_title: Through the Fire by Chaka Khan
songs.title: Through the Fire

description.plain:
“Through the Fire” is a song from Chaka Khan’s 1984 album, I Feel for You. This romantic song is about someone who is so certain that she’s met the love of her life, she’s willing to put it through any test. It was written by David Foster, Tommy Keane and Cynthia Weil.

Kanye West famously sampled the hook in his 2002 single “Through the Wire.” A terrible car accident almost killed Kanye in October 2002, leaving his jaw was broken in 3 places. He had emergency surgery to have a a metal plate put in his chin. When he was in his hospital bed, with his mouth wired shut, he heard Chaka Khan’s song “Through The Fire” playing in the background on a CD player. He was just lying back, then he heard her voice melodically singing the line, “Right down to the wire, even through the fire.” The emotional appeal inspired Kanye to write and record a song about his own experiences, sampling Chaka Khan.

Kanye sped up and pitched up the hook, giving rise to his classic “Chipmunk Soul” sample style. This was a big hit, and the sample helped jump-start Kanye’s career.

songs.full_title: Ain’t Nobody by Chaka Khan
songs.title: Ain’t Nobody

description.plain: “Ain’t Nobody” is a song by American funk band Rufus and American singer Chaka Khan. It was released on November 4, 1983, as a bonus track for their live album Stompin' at the Savoy (1983). “Ain’t Nobody” quickly gathered popularity, and reached number one on the US Billboard R&B chart and number 22 on the Billboard Hot 100.[1] It has become one of Khan’s signature songs.

songs.full_title: I'm Every Woman by Chaka Khan
songs.title: I’m Every Woman

description.plain:
1978’s “I’m Every Woman,” by Chaka Khan, is about the power and connectedness of all women. The first single from Khan’s Arif Mardin-produced debut album Chaka, it rose to #21.

The track was composed by the songwriting duo of Nickolas Ashford and Valerie Simpson—best known for their hit “Ain’t No Mountain High Enough.” When Khan was informed that Ashford and Simpson had a tune for her, she got excited. Khan, in her autobiography: “When Arif told me Ashford and Simpson had written a song for me—hell, yeah, I wanted to hear it. When I did, I knew instantly that ‘I’m Every Woman’ was a song I had to sing.”

At first, Khan thought it was arrogant for her to sing “I’m Every Woman.” Khan told the St. Louis Post-Dispatch: “That’s one of the world’s great songs, but I had to grow into it. I felt embarrassed at the age I was singing it. I wasn’t old enough. I was about 30. I just felt how dare I say ‘I’m every woman, it’s all in me.’ But it’s a song I feel comfortable singing now. But in the beginning it felt pompous.”

When Ashford felt stuck during the writing process, Simpson told him to put himself in a female mindset. Simpson, on Oprah Prime: “I started playing these chords and he said, ‘I’m every woman.’ I said, ‘Yeah.’ He said, ‘I can’t feel the verse.’ I said, ‘Put your hand on your hip and dig into your feminine side. It’ll be there. Come on.’ And he just did. It just came out.”

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_jKzIWuCh_o

Will Lee plays bass on the track—he’s best known for his many years in the David Letterman band. Lee remembers basically creating the song in the studio. He told No Treble: “That was a really fun track to do. Steve Ferrone was playing drums and there was this really simple chart in front of us. There was really nothing there.”

In 1992, Whitney Houston covered “I’m Every Woman” for the soundtrack to the movie The Bodyguard. Whitney was not the first Houston involved with “I’m Every Woman”—her mother, Cissy Houston, sang backup on the original. Also: Cissy, Khan, and Simpson all appeared in the music video for Whitney’s version.

At the end of Whitney’s version, Whitney gives Khan a shout out—“Chaka Khan. Chaka!” And in the liner notes for The Bodyguard soundtrack, Khan is credited with “Inspiration.”

songs.title_with_featured: I Feel For You (Ft. Grandmaster Melle Mel & Stevie Wonder)

description.plain:
Grandmaster Melle Mel’s lines are his own; Chaka Khan’s lines are almost all from Prince’s original version.

Fun Fact: The Pointer Sisters really wanted to run wild on “I Feel for You” two years before Chaka Khan released this single. Their producer Richard Perry insisted that it didn’t suit the group’s act.

(Source: Ruth Pointer’s autobiography, Still So Excited! My Life as a Pointer Sister)

songs.full_title: Like Sugar by Chaka Khan
songs.title: Like Sugar

description.plain: “Like Sugar” marks Chaka Khan’s return to music after a nearly eleven year hiatus. With a 1970s disco feel, the song samples the 1975 disco track “(Are You Ready) Do The Bus Stop” by New York funk group Fatback Band, which regained popularity in 2017 after being used in part one of the Netflix original series The Get Down, in which it was further remixed by singer Sarah Ruba, whose additional verse is lyrically interpolated by Khan. Ruba also provides backing vocals on the track.

songs.full_title: And The Melody Still Lingers On (Night In Tunisia) by Chaka Khan
songs.title: And The Melody Still Lingers On (Night In Tunisia)
songs.title_with_featured: And The Melody Still Lingers On (Night In Tunisia)

description.plain:
According to movingtheriver.com, “[the record] was producer Arif Mardin’s idea, his mind wandering during a flight between New York and LA. The album was one song short – so how about a tribute to the bebop masters of the ’40s using the crème de la crème of the early ’80s soul/R’n’B/jazz session players? They could use Dizzy Gillespie and Frank Paparelli’s 1942 bebop classic ‘A Night In Tunisia’ as a template.

Chaka loved the idea. Mardin hoped to find a lyricist but deadlines were pending so he tackled it himself with Chaka adding the final touches. Mardin made a demo of the arrangement which cheekily inserted Charlie Parker’s famous 1946 alto break.

A lengthy chart was quickly made up (resembling a ‘Chinese laundry list written in cuneiform’, according to Mardin) which included eight spare bars for the insertion of the Parker lick.

The musicians – Casey Scheuerell on drums, David Foster and Ronnie Foster (no relation) on keys, Abe Laboriel on bass – were booked and smashed the tune in one take.

Herbie Hancock later contributed a brilliant synth solo. Chaka then added her sublime vocals. Her four-part big-band harmonies and spine-tingling ad-libs bring the song right up to date.

But there was still space for an opening head melody and a solo in the final verse. Dizzy had been sent the demo by Mardin with a note asking him to contribute. But the bebop legend replied that he would be on tour and so couldn’t make the recording session – but he suddenly arrived two days before the album’s mastering date at New York’s Atlantic Studios to add his part. The track was complete."

Though originally recorded by the song’s co-writer Carole Bayer Sager, it has seen covers by not only Chaka, but also Dionne Warwick, Joyce Kennedy, and a number of other artists from the 1980s through 2000’s.

songs.full_title: Love You All My Lifetime by Chaka Khan
songs.title: Love You All My Lifetime

description.plain:
“Love You All My Lifetime” was the lead single from Chaka Khan’s last studio album for Warner Bros. Records, 1992’s The Woman I Am.

The single leans its lovelorn lyrics up against a deceptively feel-good background, like that of a more refined Brand New Heavies anthem. The producer responsible for the shift is former Scritti Politti keyboardist David Gamson.

The song’s black-and-white video matched the grainy art-film style of the Woman I Am album cover. It featured plenty of young, bohemian dancers while Chaka tossed around her legendary mane of hair and flashed the sky-wide smile that made her early Rufus album covers iconic.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YLK_J7PJn5U

The single reached #2 on Billboard’s Soul Singles chart, and became Chaka’s fifth #1 on the Dance charts.

songs.full_title: You Belong To Me by Chaka Khan (Ft. Michael McDonald)
songs.title: You Belong To Me
songs.title_with_featured: You Belong To Me (Ft. Michael McDonald)

description.plain:
“You Belong To Me” is a cover of the hit song written by Carly Simon and Michael McDonald, the latter of The Doobie Brothers.

Although Carly Simon’s 1978 version of the song became a breakout hit, it’s The Doobie Brothers' 1977 version with a different second verse that Chaka covers here, inviting Michael McDonald himself to trade vocals with her on their fiery, soulful remake.

songs.full_title: Move Me No Mountain by Chaka Khan
songs.title: Move Me No Mountain

description.plain: This cover is without doubt one of the best tracks ever recorded by the Queen of Funk. Her control and soul builds throughout the first verse and hook, and by the second chorus her vocals will give you long lasting goosebumps. Her outstanding last note defines her fantastic talent, and we can only guess why this amazing album track wasn’t given the limelight as a single release.

songs.full_title: The Woman I Am by Chaka Khan
songs.title: The Woman I Am

description.plain:
“The Woman I Am” was released as a double A-side single along with “Give Me All.” Outside the United States, this pair of songs served as the second single release from the The Woman I Am album.

Chaka co-wrote this self-affirming pop/R&B ballad with star songwriter Brenda Russell and Academy Award-nominated actress Dyan Cannon.

songs.full_title: You Can Make The Story Right by Chaka Khan
songs.title: You Can Make The Story Right
songs.title_with_featured: You Can Make The Story Right

description.plain:
“You Can Make The Story Right” is the second single from Chaka Khan’s eighth solo album The Woman I Am. The single was only released in the US.

This quiet storm ballad about discovering (and overlooking) infidelity in a relationship maintains an ominous feel. It’s laced with light electric guitar riffs and reaches climax with chill-inducing peaks of Chaka’s mezzo soprano.

The drama of the song’s music video is driven by a troupe of modern dancers, intercut with footage of Chaka performing the song.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ja4KV4QdzjU

songs.full_title: My Love Is Alive by Chaka Khan
songs.title: My Love Is Alive

description.plain: “My Love Is Alive” is a Gary Wright cover, that was also recorded by Tata Vega in 1978 who bears a strong vocal resemblance to Chaka in both vocal tone and style of arrangement. Though the production of the song is very dated for 1984, the cuts and edits were state-of-the-art. Despite the album’s success, Chaka has expressed a certain disdain for her producer’s concession to the trend of the day.

songs.full_title: Don't Look At Me That Way by Chaka Khan
songs.title: Don’t Look At Me That Way
songs.title_with_featured: Don't Look At Me That Way

description.plain:
“Don’t Look At Me That Way” was the final single released from Chaka Khan’s last Warner Bros. album The Woman I Am. The adult contemporary big ballad written by hitmaker Diane Warren became the start of a run of adult contemporary singles for Chaka in the mid-90’s.

Though “Don’t Look” only reached #73 on UK pop charts, she later made bigger splashes with this sound on the duet “Feels Like Heaven” with Peter Cetera, the Bruce Hornsby-assisted “Love Me Still” from the Spike Lee film Clockers, and the cross-generational hit “Missing You” featuring Brandy, Tamia, and Gladys Knight from the Set It Off soundtrack.

songs.full_title: It Ain't Easy Lovin' Me by Chaka Khan
songs.title: It Ain’t Easy Lovin’ Me

description.plain: “It Ain’t Easy Lovin' Me” was a bonus track included on the Japanese CD release of Epiphany: The Best of Chaka Khan, Vol. 1. Like the other new songs on this compilation, this song was from the abandoned sessions for an album titled Dare You To Love Me. Lyrically, the artist co-written song fits the title of the abandoned album, as Chaka admits she has baggage from previous experiences that may complicate her romance.

songs.full_title: I Want by Chaka Khan
songs.title: I Want

description.plain: “I Want” is the quick-shuffling, Marcus Miller-produced third single released from Chaka Khan’s The Woman I Am album. The song only received limited promotion and a small commercial release in the United States. The jitterbuggy jam session found a home on BET though. At the time of the single’s release, it became the soundtrack behind a series of promotional commercials for syndicated ‘70s and '80s TV comedies being rerun on BET.

songs.full_title: Slow Dancin' by Chaka Khan (Ft. Rick James)
songs.title: Slow Dancin’

description.plain: “Slow Dancin'” is an album cut on Chaka Khan’s 1982 self-titled album. The slinky slow jam features electric guitar riffs and soulful horns setting a bedroom mood. Though the song was never released as a single, it did get a breakbeat-driven remix courtesy of Hank Shocklee on the Life Is A Dance: The Remix Project album in 1989. The remix samples unused ad-libs by Chaka Khan along with some outtake dialogue where Rick James can be heard quipping, “This is a very nasty record.”

songs.full_title: Chinatown by Chaka Khan
songs.title: Chinatown

description.plain: “Chinatown” is a song from Chaka Khan’s 1984 I Feel For You album which served as the B-side of the “I Feel For You” single. The choice of B-side was a smart move financially. Although the A-side was the big hit, the B-side co-written by Chaka Khan assured that her song too would bring in money riding on the literal back of the hit “I Feel For You” single.

songs.full_title: Our Love's In Danger by Chaka Khan

description.plain: An album favourite for Chaka Khan fans, this Ashford-Simpson penned track finished Naughty with a funky warning from Chaka to her absent lover, and features backing vocals from Cissy and Whitney Houston to echo her own excellent vocals.

songs.full_title: Facts Of Love by Chaka Khan
songs.title: Facts Of Love

description.plain: “Facts Of Love” is a grandiose, uptempo pop song from Chaka Khan’s album The Woman I Am. Its synth horn stabs and chorused vocals call to mind Steve Winwood’s “Higher Love” which featured Chaka’s easily identifiable ad-libs. Though “Facts of Love” with its late 80s sound wouldn’t have fared well on US radio, the song was released as a single in Japan.

body.plain: “Facts Of Love” is a grandiose, uptempo pop song from Chaka Khan’s album The Woman I Am. Its synth horn stabs and chorused vocals call to mind Steve Winwood’s “Higher Love” which featured Chaka’s easily identifiable ad-libs. Though “Facts of Love” with its late 80s sound wouldn’t have fared well on US radio, the song was released as a single in Japan.

songs.full_title: Give Me All by Chaka Khan
songs.title: Give Me All

description.plain:
“Give Me All” was released as a double A-side single along with “The Woman I Am.” Outside the United States, this pair of songs served as the second single release from the The Woman I Am album.

The slow burning song opens with a lightning strike of a melisma from Chaka Khan before breaking into a churning R&B beat.

The single featured classic house remixes by Frankie Knuckles who was previously enlisted to remix Khan’s hit “Ain’t Nobody” with former band Rufus.

Is That All There Is? Lyrics"I remember when I was a very little girl, our house caught on fire
I'll never forget the look on my father's face as he gathered me up in his arms
And raced through the burning building out to the pavement
I stood there shivering in my pajamas and watched the whole world go up in flames
And when it was all over I said to myself
'Is that all there is to a fire?'"

Is that all there is?
Is that all there is?
If that's all there is, my friends
Then let's keep dancing
Let's break out the booze
And have a ball
If that's all there is

"And when I was 12 years old, my father took me to the circus, the greatest show on earth
There were clowns and elephants and dancing bears and a beautiful lady in pink tights flew high above our heads
And as I sat there watching the marvelous spectacle, I had the feeling that something was missing
I don't know what, but when it was over I said to myself
'Is that all there is to a circus?'"
Is that all there is?
Is that all there is?
If that's all there is, my friends
Then let's keep dancing
Let's break out the booze
And have a ball
If that's all there is

"Then I fell in love with the most wonderful boy in the world
We would take long walks by the river or just sit for hours gazing into each other's eyes
We were so very much in love. Then one day, he went away
And I thought I'd die, but I didn't
And when I didn't, I said to myself
'Is that all there is to love?'"

Is that all there is?
Is that all there is?
If that's all there is, my friends
Then let's keep dancing

"I know what you must be saying to yourselves
'If that's the way she feels about it why doesn't she just end it all?'
Oh, no. Not me. I'm in no hurry for that final disappointment
For I know just as well as I'm standing here talking to you
When that final moment comes and I'm breathing my last breath
I'll be saying to myself..."
Is that all there is?
Is that all there is?
If that's all there is, my friends
Then let's keep dancing
Let's break out the booze
And have a ball
If that's all there isEmbed

songs.lyrics:
The christmas song LyricsChestnuts roasting on an open fire
Jack Frost nipping at your nose
Yule-tide carols being sung by a choir
And folks dressed up like Eskimos

Everybody knows a turkey and some mistletoe
Help to make the season bright
Tiny tots with their eyes all aglow
Will find it hard to sleep tonight

They know that Santa's on his way
He's loaded lots of toys and goodies on his sleigh
And every mother's child is gonna spy
To see if reindeer really know how to fly

And so I'm offering this simple phrase
To kids from one to ninety-two
Although it's been said many times, many ways
Merry Christmas to you!Embed

songs.full_title: Dare You To Love Me by Chaka Khan
songs.title: Dare You To Love Me

description.plain:
“Dare You To Love Me” is intended to be the title song of an unreleased Chaka Khan album from 1995.  The song bears the hallmarks of David Gamson’s production. Gamson also produced other songs from this time period like “Don’t Take Back (Your Love),” “Pain,” “Love You All My Lifetime,” and “Never Miss The Water.”

Khan spoke in her 2003 autobiography Chaka! Through The Fire about how proud she was of this work in the face of record label discouragement:

At times they had me questioning myself — Am I a good singer? Am I chopped liver? Am I a piece of … ?
Then I’d hear my voice. I knew my voice. I’d hear what I can do—I’d think back to times I’d been sick as a dog, and the show went on because when I get into that zone, into that spiritual place where my voice lives, I detach from my body. I’d hear my voice and know…But some Warner execs wanted me to believe that without them I was nothing.

This track from the album went unreleased until it leaked circa 2010. Khan would later highlight the song’s appearance on her official Twitter account:
https://twitter.com/ChakaKhan/status/844970352690159616

songs.full_title: Pain by Chaka Khan
songs.title: Pain

description.plain:
“Pain” was a song recorded for Chaka Khan’s shelved 1995 album Dare You To Love Me. The song, co-written by Prince, Rosie Gaines, and Gaines' then-husband D. Channsin Berry.

Gaines' original recording was to be a track on her own solo album Concrete Jungle in 1993. The song was a B-side on her single release of “My Tender Heart,” but when the relationship between her record label Paisley Park and its distributor Warner Bros. went bad, Gaines' solo album was cancelled.

This left “Pain” up grabs, but the song was again buried when Khan’s album got shelved. Khan’s recording of “Pain,” however, finally surfaced in 1997 on the soundtrack of the TV series Living Single.
